text: it's certainly not unusual to get stormy
weather in the North Atlantic at this
time of the year as we found out last
winter of course but sometimes these
storms can go through a rapid period of
intensification that's something that's
occasionally known as a weather bomb
that's actually derived from the
meteorological term which is explosive
cyclogenesis essentially just means that
the pressure in the center of the storm
drops away very rapidly over a fairly
short period of time the definition
being 24-minute bars falling pressure in
the space of 24 hours now with a storm
sitting in the North Atlantic and wind's
blowing from one side of the Atlantic to
the other at severe gale-force or above
that gives plenty of space for some
really big waves to build up and we're
talking about waves getting as high as
18 meters over open waters compare that
to well a two-story house at around 8
meters a double-decker bus at just 4
meters huge waves that's over open water
the ways tend to lose some of their
height and energy as they head towards
the shore
